Graphical abstract Hydrogenase, nature’s gift to scientists, is the paradigm catalyst for hydrogen production and utilization. Hydrogenase is a paradigm of highly efficient biocatalyst for H2 production and utilization evolved in nature. A dilemma is that despite the high activity and efficiency expected for hydrogenases as promising catalysts for the hydrogen economy, the poor oxygen tolerance and low yield of hydrogenases largely hinder their practical application. In these years, the enigmas surrounding hydrogenases regarding their structures, oxygen tolerance, mechanisms for catalysis, redox intermediates, and proton-coupled electron transfer schemes have been gradually elucidated; the schemes, which can well couple hydrogenases with other highly efficient (in)organic and biological catalysts to build novel reactors and drive valuable reactions, make it possible for hydrogenases to find their niches. To see how scientists put efforts to tackle this issue and design novel reactors in the fields where hydrogenases play crucial roles, in this review, recent advances were summarized, including different strategies for protecting enzyme molecules from oxygen, enzyme-based assembling systems for H2 evolution in the photoelectronic catalysis, enzymatic biofuel cells for H2 utilization and storage and the efficient electricity-hydrogen-carbohydrate cycle for high-purity hydrogen and biofuel automobiles. Limitations and future perspectives of hydrogenase-based applications in H2 production and utilization with great impact are discussed. In addition, this review also provides a new perspective on the use of biohydrogen in healthcare beyond energy. Keywords Hydrogenase Biological H2 energy Oxygen tolerance Artificial photosynthesis Biofuel cells 1 Introduction Energy is a central topic of the 21st century. With the rapid industrialization and population growth of human society, the concern of global reliance on fossil fuels, such as natural gas and coal, is increasingly growing. Importantly, large-scale emissions of CO2, SO2, and nitrous oxide particles arising from continuous consumption of fossil fuels, serve as the predominant sources of global warming and severe pollution [1–3]. Due to the non-renewable nature and uneven regional distribution of fossil fuels, it remains a great challenge to meet humankind’s huge and growing demand for energy [4]. Dihydrogen (H2) is one of the most promising carbon-free secondary energy converted from primary energy and an important industrial raw material with high energy density, abundant sources to generate, and great sustainability [5,6]. Ideally, people could make full use of H2 energy directly by combustion or indirectly by exploiting H2-based fuel cells, with water as the only product [7,8]. However, industrial H2 production still relies on fossil fuels heavily which is inevitably an energy-intensive and CO2 generating process [9]. Other emerging H2 production methods, with the (photo)electrochemical water splitting systems as typical examples, are potentially more eco-friendly, but right now still heavily exploit noble metal-based catalysts [10–12]. Alternatively, if transition metal-based catalysts were used, an overpotential is often required to reach considerable current density [13–16]. The water splitting reaction is an uphill process, requiring a minimum energy of 1.23 eV, as the Gibbs free energy change for the reaction shown in Eq. (1) is △G 0 = 237.2 kJ mol−1 [5]. (1) H2O → H2 + ½O2, △G 0 = 237.2 kJ mol−1 Hydrogenases are a group of powerful metalloenzymes for H2 evolution and utilization evolved in nature [17]. In terms of the activity per catalytic unit, hydrogenases are comparable to platinum. For example, as one of the most efficient variants, the [FeFe]-hydrogenase from Desulfovibrio desulfuricans (Dd) is among the most efficient H2 producers and users, with over 100,000 s−1 and 10,000 s−1 turnover frequency (TOF) for H2 oxidation and proton reduction, respectively [18,19]. The preparation of hydrogenases does not involve any noble metal or common pollutant, which make them promising biocatalysts for hydrogen economy. However, before their large-scale applications in either artificial systems for H2 production [20] or utilization in biofuel cells [21], the poor performance of hydrogenases in the presence of O2 has been a major obstacle that needs to be well addressed. Based on this fact, in this review, the tertiary structures and active sites relevant to O2 binding and mainstream strategies to address the O2 sensitivity issue of hydrogenases are summarized first. After fully considering and absorbing various factors accounting for O2 sensitivity of hydrogenases, recent state-of-the-art hydrogenase-catalyzed (photo)electrochemical H2 production schemes, hydrogenase-based biofuel cells (HBFCs) systems and future perspectives are discussed in the remaining sections. 2 Enhance the O2 tolerance of hydrogenases This section introduces the basic structures and O2 sensitivity properties of different hydrogenases and summarizes recent strategies for improving the performance of hydrogenases under aerobic conditions, which include the mutation of amino acid residues relevant to the functionality of the gas channel, the [FeS] clusters and the active site, the exploitation of external forces to decrease the detrimental effects brought about by O2, and an overall modification of the organism. 2.1 Basic structures of hydrogenases and origins of O2 sensitivity Hydrogenases can be classified into [FeFe]-, [NiFe]-, and [Fe]-hydrogenases based on the structures of their active sites which are composed of varying metal ions and ligands. This review will mainly focus on more commonly discussed and studied [FeFe]- and [NiFe]-hydrogenases (Fig. 1 a and b). [FeFe]-hydrogenases are among the most active H2-producing biocatalysts. In contrast to standard [NiFe]-hydrogenases of which the H2-producing activity is significantly inhibited under excess H2 partial pressure, [FeFe]-hydrogenases are observed with much smaller inhibition effect [22]. As extreme O2-sensitive enzymes, most [FeFe]-hydrogenases are irreversibly inactivated even by trace amounts of O2 in seconds [23]. Fig. 1(a) shows the structure of the CpI-[FeFe]-hydrogenase from Clostridium pasteurianum (Cp) [24]. In the catalytic “H-domain,” which is shared by all [FeFe]-hydrogenases, there is an active site H-cluster comprised of a diiron site and a cubane [4Fe-4S] cluster (Fig. 1c) connected via a sulfur of a cysteine (Cys) residue. The two iron metals are bridged by a di-sulfur bridgehead and a CO ligand. Except for the bridging ligands, both the distal iron (Fed) and the proximal iron (Fep) are coordinated by one CO and one CN– ligand, respectively. The [4Fe-4S] cluster is coordinated by four Cys residues among which one is strictly conserved and additionally coordinates the diiron site [25]. Aside from the “H-domain”, CpI has an extra “F-domain” containing four iron-sulfur clusters as the electron relay to mediate fast intramolecular and interfacial electron transfer [26]. Fig. 1(d) illustrates an electron delivery process using the [NiFe]-hydrogenase with three [FeS] clusters as a model. For CrHydA1-[FeFe]-hydrogenase from the green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii (Cr), which has only an “H-cluster” with no internal [FeS] cluster, poor electron transfer kinetics was recorded [27]. In the O2 exposure, the produced reactive oxygen species (ROS) can irreversibly destroy the [4Fe-4S] cluster and the diiron site, thus fully inactivating the [FeFe]-hydrogenases [28]. There are a limited number of [FeFe]-hydrogenases that form a special “Hinact” oxidized state which can be reactivated. In the case of the CbHydA1 hydrogenase from Clostridium beijerinckii (Cb), the “Hinact” can last up to 40 h under aerobic conditions [29]. The first coordination sphere of the H-cluster is believed to be important for this phenomenon. In the Hinact state, the open coordination site (Fep) can combine a ligand, such as the OH–, S--Cys, and OS--Cys models in CbHydA1 [30], and the SH- in DdHydAB from Desulfovibrio desulfuricans (Dd) [18], which provide extra protection for the active site against O2 attack. The [NiFe]-hydrogenase from Desulfovibrio fructosovorans (Df, shown in Fig. 1b) is composed of two subunits of which the small one (about 30 kDa) contains three [FeS] clusters as the electron relay and the large one (about 60 kDa) accommodates the [NiFe] active site for 2H+/H2 conversion [31]. Two CN– and one CO are coordinated with the Fe site. Four sulfur atoms from four conserved Cys residues are coordinated with the Ni, and two of them are shared by the Fe as the bridging ligands. Standard [NiFe]-hydrogenase is sensitive to O2. Under aerobic conditions and electron-poor conditions, the [NiFe] active center rapidly transforms from active state into two distinct inactive oxidized (Ni(III)) states, namely the ready (Ni-B) and unready (Ni-A) states, with the difference being that the Ni-B state reactivates much faster than Ni-A state under reducing conditions [23]. There is another large class of [NiFe]-hydrogenases that only turn into the Ni-B state when being oxidized in the air. Such O2-tolerant hydrogenases are characterized by owning a unique [4Fe-3S] cluster in the proximal position to the active site [32]. Oxygen tolerant membrane-bound [NiFe]-hydrogenase H16 from Ralstonia eutropha (Re) and hydrogenase-1 (Hyd-1) from Escherichia coli (E. coli) are representatives that can hold H2 uptake in the presence of ambient O2 in which case the associated internal electron transfer chain is critical to accounting for O2 tolerance. The proximal [4Fe-3S] cluster is surrounded by six instead of four conserved coordinating cysteines in standard [NiFe]-hydrogenases. The removal of two of these additional cysteines changes the electronic structure of this [FeS] cluster and makes the enzyme sensitive to O2 [33]. Due to such unique coordination configuration of iron, this proximal [FeS] cluster can contribute two electrons consecutively to ensure a complete reduction of O2 to H2O at the active site when O2 attacks [34]. A side effect of being an O2 tolerant [NiFe]-hydrogenase is that the electrode potentials of all [FeS] clusters are usually more positive than those observed for standard [NiFe]-hydrogenases such that during a catalytic cycle, the electrons feeding the active site are too de-energized to drive H2 production [35]. There also exists a group of non-standard and structurally more complicated [NiFe]-hydrogenase called the soluble hydrogenase (SH) or NAD(P)+-reducing hydrogenase [36,37]. These enzymes often consist of a heterodimeric hydrogenase moiety which resembles that of standard [NiFe]-hydrogenases for the bidirectional hydrogen reaction and a multimeric flavin-containing module for the reduction of the nicotinamide cofactor NAD(P)+. Soluble hydrogenases can be either O2 sensitive or partially O2 tolerant, as examples can be found in both cases. Importantly, the SH from the hyperthermophile P. furiosus (Pf) is a representative with impressive thermostability and O2 tolerance [36]. Examples of this enzyme will be discussed in details in Section 5. It should be noted that the origins accounting for the O2 tolerance of SHs are still under discussion and are markedly different from those of the usual O2 tolerant hydrogenase like Hyd-1 from E. coli. This is because SHs do not contain the special [4Fe-3S] cluster and the inactive states are different from Ni-A or Ni-B. In addition, nature has also evolved a particular subgroup - the [NiFeSe]-hydrogenase with special resistance towards O2. The overall structure of [NiFeSe]-hydrogenases resemble common [NiFe]-hydrogenases with the main difference being that one of the terminal cysteines ligated with Ni is replaced by a selenocysteine (SeCys) (Fig. 1b) [17]. While the inactive states of standard O2 sensitive and tolerant [NiFe] species are electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) active Ni(III) (either Ni-A or Ni-B), the oxidation species of [NiFeSe]-hydrogenases are only EPR silent Ni(II) states instead. Under aerobic conditions, X-ray crystallography results of [NiFeSe]-hydrogenases show that the selenium in some inactive structures was oxidized, suggesting that this mechanism may protect Ni from being over-oxidized into Ni(III). As selenium is easier than sulfur to reduce and the bigger size of selenium than sulfur can offer extra steric hindrance in the gas channel, these factors may all contribute to quick reactivation of [NiFeSe]-hydrogenases under reducing conditions [38]. In short, regarding the origin of O2 tolerance, for common O2 tolerant [NiFe]-hydrogenases, it is proposed that when O2 attacks the [NiFe] active site, only the easily reduced Ni-B state finally forms, while the [NiFeSe]-hydrogenase is suggested to have another hypothetical mechanism: the introduction of selenium providing extra protection and steric hindrance against O2 [39]. 2.2 Enzyme evolution to achieve higher oxygen tolerance The strategies to enhance the O2 tolerance of hydrogenases (Fig. 2 ) can be roughly categorized into the bioengineering strategies (left panels), where genetic modification is carried out to increase the intrinsic resistance of hydrogenases against O2, and material assisting strategies (right panels), in which case synthetic materials are used to provide the protection externally. As for [NiFe]-hydrogenase, a highly conserved ∼30 Å long gas channel goes through the [FeS]-cluster-containing subunit. At the very end of this tunnel close to Ni locates the backbone of residue Glu28 and the lateral chains of Val78 and Leu126 (corresponding to the sequence number of Hyd-1-[NiFe]-hydrogenase) [40]. Based on this fact, del Barrio et al. mutated the conserved valine residue (Val78) near the Ni metal to cysteine (V78C) and successfully improved the O2 tolerance of Hyd-1. One resulting consequence for this V78C variant is a ∼20-fold lower activity compared to the wildtype Hyd-1 [41], which is mainly due to the delivery of H2 substrate being restricted by the “narrower” tunnel. The Df-[NiFe]-hydrogenase is O2 sensitive with Val74 (corresponding to V78 in Hyd-1 [NiFe]-hydrogenase) at the bottleneck of the gas channel near the active site [42]. Aerobic inactivation of the wildtype of this hydrogenase mainly produces the “unready” Ni-A state, while the variant V74C predominantly gives rise to the Ni-B form (Fig. 3 a) [43]. Such a marked shift from an “unready” oxidized state to an easily reduced state is a clear demonstration of improved O2 tolerance. As one usual consequence of altering the gas channel by site-directed mutation is a much lower observed activity of [NiFe]-hydrogenase on H2, ensuing efforts have been made to avoid such negative effects while still increasing the O2 tolerance. As mentioned earlier, O2 tolerant [NiFe]-hydrogenases, like the H16 from Re and Hyd-1 from E. coli, have a special proximal [4Fe-3S] cluster that is coordinated by six rather than four Cys residues as the case in the standard [NiFe]-hydrogenases [17]. It is believed the two additional Cys residues should play a crucial role in contributing O2 tolerant properties [41,43] and bio-engineering based on this fact is a good starting point. In [NiFeSe]-hydrogenase, as the SeCys residue points inwardly, the tunnel can obstruct the inhibitory CO and O2 molecules moving towards the active site. A work demonstrated the importance of Se by replacing the natural SeCys residue of [NiFeSe]-hydrogenase with a cysteine, making it similar to the “O2-sensitive” [NiFe]-hydrogenase [45]. This inspired researchers that designing a variant by replacing the terminal Cys ligated with Ni to SeCys to give a [NiFeSe]-hydrogenase-like enzyme [43] will provide more insights in terms of developing efficient synthetic catalysts and understanding more detailed mechanisms that contribute to O2 tolerance (Fig. 1b) [46]. Regarding the [FeFe]-hydrogenase, Koo et al. designed a suite of variants with mutation sites near the proximal and medial [FeS] clusters of the CpI. Among them, two variants (T356V and S357T) were screened, which could maintain H2 production activity and improve O2 tolerance [47]. Ferredoxin (Fd) is an important molecule in vivo that mediates rapid O2 reduction. A feasible hydrogenase protection strategy is to utilize the O2 reduction properties of Fd to protect hydrogenase from being damaged by O2 (Fig. 3b) [48]. A similar strategy was used to protect [FeFe]-hydrogenase HydA from Cr. The resulting fused enzyme has ∼4.5 times higher photosynthetic hydrogen-producing rate in vivo and is more O2 tolerant than native HydA [49]. These studies strongly support the feasibility that combining biological O2-reducing catalysts and O2-sensitive hydrogenase into a single entity leads to efficient biocatalysts operated under aerobic conditions. 2.3 Protective layer to resist inactivation by O2 A parallel and cooperative protection strategy usually applies redox protective layers into which hydrogenase molecules are encompassed such that O2 is physically blocked or consumed externally. This section will include recent advances regarding this topic. First, viologen-modified redox layers were utilized to protect hydrogenase from O2 attack. In 2014, Plumeré et al. developed a redox hydrogel that can protect the [NiFe]-hydrogenase from Desulfovibrio vulgaris Miyazaki F (DvMF) from high-potential deactivation and oxygen damage (Fig. 3c) [50]. They chose branched polyethyleneimine as the backbone, and covalently bound viologen moieties as the redox relays, followed by the thioacetate, which could provide mild cross-linking conditions for the formation of stable hydrogel films. The polarity of the backbone contributed to the requisite solubility of the assembly containing the polymer and hydrogenase molecules. Fast electron transfer (ET) and O2 scavenging properties of viologen can control the potential of the hydrogenase active site, thus protecting the enzyme molecules from high-potential inactivation and oxidative stress. As a result, the DvMF-[NiFe]-hydrogenase could maintain activity under 5% O2 and high potential conditions. The same research group modified this redox hydrogel to protect the much more O2 sensitive CrHydA1-[FeFe]-hydrogenase. The resulting system maintained H2 oxidizing activity in the presence of 5% O2 and 95% H2 for up to 5 min, and when the gas feed was changed back to 100% H2, the catalytic current could be fully recovered [54]. The viologen-modified low potential redox polymer was also exploited to provide effective protection for [NiFeSe]-hydrogenase from Desulfovibrio vulgaris Hildenborough (DvH), which was reactivated after being operated under 5% O2 [55]. Oughli et al. developed a redox silent polymer matrix that can be separated into two reaction layers. In the inner “active” layer close to the electrode, the hydrogenase oxidized H2 and exchanged electrons with the electrode, while in the outer “protection” layer, the catalyst converted O2 to H2O, thereby providing the “active” layer with a barrier against O2 [56]. To avoid redundant biocatalyst loading and mass transport limitations for thick films (>100 μm), a thinner film (down to 3 μm) of redox polymer was developed and applied to protect the Df-[NiFe]-hydrogenase under 5% O2 (Fig. 3d), in which case the viologen-modified dendrimers were used as building blocks for the assembly of the redox matrix and the thioacetate group was used as the cross-linking chemical. The life time of a 6 μm film was predicted to be up to 1 year [51]. Interestingly, some oxidases can co-work with the viologen-modified redox layer to protect hydrogenase from O2 destruction. A low-potential viologen-modified polymer formed by the polymer matrix P(N3MA-BA-GMA)-vio, (poly (3-azido-propyl methacrylate-co-butyl acrylate-co-glycidyl methacrylate)-viologen, served as the low-potential layer to avoid high-potential inactivation of hydrogenase. A second O2-removing protection layer, formed by the redox-silent polymer with a backbone of P(SS-GMA-BA) (poly(4-styrenesulfonate-co-glycidyl methacrylate-co-butyl acrylate) within which glucose oxidase (GOx) and catalase (CAT) were entrapped, was introduced on the top of the P(N3MA-BA-GMA)-vio-hydrogenase layer to fast reduce O2, H2O2 and other ROS to H2O, thus preventing the hydrogenase from being inactivated [57]. Even without oxygen consumption, there are peptide-based hydrogels that can physically block the oxygen diffusion and make the hydrogenase keep its activity. The fluorenyl-methyl-oxy-carbonyl-diphenylalanine aromatic dipeptide (FmocFF) is a typical hydrogel network that can thoroughly coat hydrogenase spontaneously (Fig. 3E). Theoretical calculation and analysis showed that different configurations of aromatic rings of FmocFF can produce the hydrophobic interaction. These hydrophobic pockets provide extra steric hindrance and block the diffusion of O2, with little influence on the diffusion of H2. The O2-sensitive CrHydA1-[FeFe]-hydrogenase in this FmocFF hydrogel could retain 25% activity under ambient air with an I50 of 30 min, compared to only several seconds when aerobically exposing CrHydA1 alone [52]. In addition to the aforementioned, the more impressive strategy is to engineer organisms into core–shell structures. Carboxysome shells were constructed in E. coli by expressing a set of carboxysome protein-encoding genes. The produced shell encapsulation and the internal microenvironment can protect the HydA-[FeFe]-hydrogenase from Cr and facilitate H2 production in vivo and in vitro (Fig. 3F). The H2 evolution rate of the shell-HydA using MV as the electron mediator was approximately 5.5-fold greater than that of free HydA. After being exposed in the air for 24 h, the shell-HydA retained 13% of its initial activity, compared to only 0.97% being observed for free HydA [53]. 3 Solar hydrogen evolution Solar energy is the most abundant and accessible form of renewable energy. In contrast to biological photosynthesis, using solar energy to produce fuels without a living organism is defined as artificial photosynthesis (AP) [58]. Artificial photosynthetic strategies can convert solar energy into chemical energy stored in high-energy bonds of distinct compounds, among which hydrogen restored from water is an ideal candidate to meet future renewable energy requirements [20,59–61]. This part focuses on recent advances for photobiological H2 production that combine hydrogenases with dyes (Fig. 4 a), semiconductors (Fig. 4b), and photoelectrochemical devices (Fig. 4c). Results of some representative works are summarized in Table S1 (in Supplementary Data). 3.1 Hydrogenase and dye assembly In early studies, organic dyes were used to provide photogenerated electrons for hydrogenases, in which case the photogenerated electrons were first mediated by an electron mediator. However, a competing process exists in many shuttle redox ion pairs that tend to spontaneously accept or donate electrons owing to their moderate redox potentials, which inevitably causes large energy loss and decreases the quantum yield [62]. To promote the ET, an organic dye Eosin Y (EY) was directly wired with [NiFeSe]-hydrogenase from Desulfomicrobium baculatum (Db) (Fig. 5 a), with a TOF of 13.9 s−1 being recorded. This system displayed significant O2 tolerance, with observable H2-producing activity persisting for up to three hours under 21% O2 [63]. Apart from organic dyes, natural dyes can also be used to generate photocarriers for enzymatic catalysis. Subsequently, Photosystem I (PSI) and Photosystem II (PSII) were separated and fabricated to carry out comprehensive studies of light-driven water splitting. To streamline the ET between the photosystems and hydrogenase, the protein molecules were linked directly via molecular wires, redox polymer, or protein subunits (Fig. 5b) [64,65]. However, these in vitro systems are generally short-lived because metabolic processes that support self-repair and maintenance were absent. Appel et al. reported an in vivo H2-producing method using a PSI-hydrogenase (PsaD-HoxYH) fusion complex [65]. The [NiFe]-hydrogenase HoxYH from the cyanobacterium Synechocstis sp. PCC 6803 was fused to the subunit PsaD of PSI near a [4Fe-4S] cluster which mediates the ET to the Fd. Under light illumination, the resulting PsaD-HoxYH mutant could grow autotrophically, achieved anaerobic H2 production up to 500 μM, and did not take up the generated H2. 3.2 Hydrogenase and semiconductor integrated systems Single semiconductors such as CdTe nanoparticles (NPs) and CdS nanorods (NRs) modified with 3-mercaptopropionic acid can act as the photosensitizer and active scaffold for protein molecules. The photogenerated electrons could transfer from the conduction band (CB) to the distal [4Fe-4S] cluster of the hydrogenase within 100 ns [69] with >20% quantum yield [70]. As a metal-free and visible-light-responsive photocatalyst, polymeric carbon nitride (CNx) has drawn broad attention to coupling hydrogenase for clean solar-H2 energy [71]. A CNx-hydrogenase hybrid could remain active after 48 h of illumination, and the turnover number (TON) reached 50,000 mol H2 (mol hydrogenase)−1. To further broaden the light absorption range and enhance the mutual interaction between photosensitizers and hydrogenases, dye-sensitized semiconductors or heterostructures such as CNx-TiO2 were used (Fig. 5c). As the surface of Db-[NiFeSe]-hydrogenase close to the [4Fe-4S] cluster is rich in glutamic and aspartic amino residues having high affinity with TiO2, Caputo and his coworkers immobilized the enzyme on a CNx-TiO2 heterojunction and achieved a TON of more than 5.8 × 105 mol H2 (mol hydrogenase)−1 in 72 h under solar light illumination [66]. Hydrogenases and light-harvesting assemblies can be linked by the “hard-wiring” strategy. A recent example is the exploitation of silver nanoclusters (AgNCs) developed by Zhang et al., which, as a powerful photosensitizer, can reduce MV under visible light and can specifically bond with surface-exposed cysteines of enzymes through the Ag-S interaction [59]. When this Ag-S interaction is close to the distal cluster of variants of Hyd-2 [NiFe]-hydrogenase from E. coli, photogenerated electrons can be injected directly into the protein (Fig. 5f). Under visible light irradiation, 193 s−1 TOF and 20% quantum yield were reached, and TiO2 was proposed to mediate the transfer of holes [59]. Based on this, Zhang et al. later reported a Z-scheme-like photocatalytic assembly comprised of a variant of Hyd-1 [NiFe]-hydrogenase from E. coli, AgNCs, and the TiO2/g-C3N4 heterojunction. In this system, it was proposed that photo-induced electrons were transferred from the CB of g-C3N4 to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of AgNCs, and were ultimately transferred from AgNCs to the engineered surface cysteine groups close to both the distal [4Fe-4S] and medial [3Fe-4S] clusters. Importantly, the Hyd-1 enzyme, which intrinsically does not have H2-producing capability, was activated and could catalyze H2 production at a TOF of 40 s−1 [35]. It is believed that the covalently bound AgNCs assumed the role of “electrochemical control site” (ECS) like [FeS] clusters and thus altered the potential bias of the 2H+/H2 reaction catalyzed by Hyd-1. 3.3 Hydrogenase and photoelectrochemical device The construction of a photocatalytic full water-splitting system is a promising strategy without the need of sacrificial donor (SED) to scavenge the oxidative side reactions. Silicon (Si) has a narrow band gap of 1.1 eV and is widely used as an efficient photocathode for proton reduction, with a CB energy level of approximately 0.5 V vs. normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) and a band gap (Eg) of 1.12 eV [72]. Zhao et al. reported fabricated nanoporous black silicon (b-Si) photoelectrodes using an Ag-assisted etching method, which improved the loading capacity of the electrode [73]. The assembled [FeFe]-hydrogenase/b-Si photoelectrode achieved H2 production at a TOF above 1300 s−1 and a TON of ≥ 107 under sunlight with an active enzyme loading coverage of 12 pmol cm−2. The p-type semiconductor Cu2O has a suitable band gap (2 eV) for visible light absorption and spot-on CB and VB energy levels for proton reduction and water oxidation with driving forces of 0.7 and 0.17 V, respectively [74]. Based on this fact, Tian et al. introduced ZnO, a band gap matched n-type semiconductor, onto the top of Cu2O, which not only protected Cu2O from photo-corrosion but also constructed a p-n heterojunction structure [75]. A [FeFe]-hydrogenase was integrated into the composite electrode to give a bio-photocatalytic assembly for rapid H2 production. Under light illumination, a photocurrent density of 0.8 mA cm−2 at 0.15 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) was obtained, and H2 was detected with a Faradaic efficiency of ca. 1%. Organic-inorganic lead halide perovskites are characterized by low production costs and promising photovoltaic (PV) cell efficiencies. First-principles calculations suggested that the lead halide-based perovskite cathodes perform better than their conventional counterparts in terms of H2 production [76]. However, extra sensitivity and instability of these perovskite materials under different moisture, gas, and temperature conditions have challenged their wider use in photoelectrochemical (PEC) devices [77]. Encapsulated perovskites with metal foils and epoxy resin can improve the service lifetime of solution-immersed perovskite-based photoelectrodes from seconds to hours [78]. Moore et al. encapsulated the perovskite using a eutectic alloy, metal foil, and epoxy resin and integrated the [NiFeSe]-hydrogenase into a hierarchical IO-TiO2 scaffold (Fig. 5d) [67]. This biomaterial hybrid with a single-compartment “leaf” configuration, was stable for up to 12 h under a liquid environment and achieved a current density of −5 mA cm−2 at 0 V vs. RHE, a positive onset potential of +0.8 V vs. RHE, an H2 production yield of 258 ± 55 μmol H2 cm−2 and a TON of 1.9 × 106 of hydrogenase-based H2 production under AM 1.5G irradiation. Photosystem II is an integral part of the thylakoid membrane and utilizes visible light (∼400–700 nm) to drive O2-evolving water oxidation, which is an ideal representative biocatalyst to couple with hydrogenase. Mersch et al. developed a tailor-made hierarchically structured indium tin oxide (ITO) electrode that integrated PSII and hydrogenase [79]. Since the system could only deal with low-energy red light absorption, an additional bias (>0.6 V) was required to drive the complete reaction. Nam and coworkers introduced Si into an IO-TiO2|hydrogenase (IO = indium oxide) photocathode to overcome the overpotential and integrated PSII with a BiVO4 photoanode [80]. Compared with the previous PSII-based PEC tandem cell, this system required a much less minimal potential bias of 0.24 V and realized a Faradaic efficiency of 91 ± 19%. Wiring PSII with PSI can mimic a full light-driven Z-scheme bio-PV cell (Fig. 5e). Schuhmann et al. reported PSI monolayers being immobilized on a bio-photocathode in a controllable manner with favoring orientation that gave rise to anisotropic electron flow under light irradiation. Efficient electron transfer and minimized short-circuiting pathways were ensured by the additional interface of the PSI monolayer with redox polymers. To reach the functionality of the bio-photocathode, the PSI monolayer was coupled to a hydrogenase to drive H2 production. With the introduction of a second biocathode comprised of PSII and a redox polymer, the resulting system can achieve full water splitting with no potential bias [68]. 4 Biofuel cells for hydrogen energy conversion and utilization In the field of bioelectrochemistry, biofuel cells (BFCs) are expected to play important roles in aerospace, biomedicine, transportation, communication, and so on [81]. The enzymatic biofuel cells (EBFCs) are a class of energy conversion devices that exploit purified oxidoreductases as the biocatalyst, renewable biomass such as glucose [82], xylose [83], ethanol, and hydrogen as the fuel, and an electrode upon which enzymes are immobilized to convert the chemical energy stored in the fuel into electric energy [21]. In a typical EBFC set-up, two enzymatic electrodes are utilized to catalyze two separate half-reactions, or alternatively, there exists only one enzymatic bioelectrode (usually the anode) to catalyze the reaction of interest. In the case of a dual bioelectrode-containing set-up, the substrate of the anode reaction is oxidized, with electrons flowing to the biocathode through the external circuit, followed by the corresponding enzyme-catalyzed reduction reaction [84]. In EBFCs, the electron flow between enzymes and electrodes is mainly accomplished by what defined as direct electron transfer (DET) and mediated electron transfer (MET). For DET, electrons can be transferred to and from the surface-exposed redox site and the electrode surface directly. In a MET model instead, redox mediators are used to shuttle electrons between the enzyme and electrode [85]. Compared to synthetic catalysts, the operating conditions of EBFCs are relatively mild. The nature of the enzymatic reaction enables EBFCs to work at physiological pH, room temperature, and ambient pressure. Furthermore, oxidoreductases have high selectivity on their natural substrates, thus allowing the assembly of bioanode and biocathode in a single-compartment membrane-less cell and miniaturizing EBFCs [86]. Importantly, as enzymes are biodegradable, EBFCs generally do not cause much concern in subsequent issues like pollution and materials recycling. This part focuses on HBFCs and highlight examples using hydrogenase as the anode catalyst and H2 as the feedstock. 4.1 Hydrogenase and oxidase HBFCs for electric energy As seen in Fig. 6 , the application of hydrogenase-based EBFCs can be classified into two subgroups. The first one is for generating electric energy (panel a), with a coupled biocathode exploiting an O2-reducing oxidoreductase to convert O2 into water. The second one is for obtaining high value-added products (panel b), with a biocathode loaded with electroactive enzymes to carry out downstream reactions. Some representative works in HBFCs for the utilization of H2 energy are summarized in Table S2. The main limitations that hinder the application of hydrogenases in HBFCs are O2 sensitivity, stability, and low current density. Currently, there exist three strategies to improve the performance of hydrogenases under aerobic conditions: (1) using O2 tolerant hydrogenases, (2) modifying hydrogenases to enhance O2 tolerance through protein engineering, (3) integrating hydrogenases into redox polymer films. As previously shown and discussed in Fig. 3(c), the O2-sensitive DvMF-[NiFe]-hydrogenase was integrated into a specially designed MV-based redox polymer, providing protection for the enzyme from O2 damage and high potential inactivation. The biocathode was constructed by covalently linking the bilirubin oxidase (BOD) with a piece of carbon cloth. The assembled enzymatic fuel cells were continuously monitored, with the open circuit voltage (947 ± 3 mV), short circuit current (323 ± 52 µA cm−2), maximum power density (178 ± 19 μW cm−2), and half-life of H2 generation activity (ca. one day) being recorded [50]. Li et al. found that H2O2 arising from incomplete reduction of O2 in the above work was the main reason for the decomposition of the redox matrix. They showed that efficient disproportionation of H2O2 by iodide could extend the aerobic half-life of the catalytic membranes containing O2-sensitive [NiFe]-hydrogenases to more than one week. By coupling a hydrogenase-modified anode with an O2-reducing cathode modified with BOD in a two-compartment cell, the assembled fuel cell reached a current density of 117 ± 30 µA cm−2 and a power density of 5.8 ± 1.2 μW cm−2 [87]. Hardt et al. developed a redox-active film for bidirectional and reversible H2 conversion. The anode contained DdHydAB-[FeFe]-hydrogenase embedded in a low-potential 2,2′-viologen-modified hydrogel, while the cathode was a carbon felt modified with BOD from Myrothecium verrucaria (Mv). This fuel cell exhibited a maximum power output of 147 ± 14 μW cm−2 and maximum current output of 163 ± 26 μA cm−2 [88]. A polymer multilayer/hydrogenase-based bioanode was also developed [57]. The bioanode was composed of a polymer bilayer system of which the bottom layer incorporated the DvMF-[NiFe]-hydrogenase or the DvH-[NiFeSe]-hydrogenase and a viologen-modified polymer. The protective top layer consisted of a dual-enzyme system containing an oxidase (glucose oxidase, GOx, or pyranose oxidase, Py2Ox) and catalase (CAT) embedded in a redox polymer. The biocathode was built on the carbon cloth with a bottom layer immobilized with horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and a top layer containing a H2O2-scavenging oxidase (GOx or Py2Ox). A baseline open circuit voltage (OCV) of 1.15 V and a power density of up to 530 μW cm−2 at 0.85 V were recorded in this hydrogen/glucose biofuel cell (Fig. 7 a). A benchmark for a hydrogenase/redox polymer-based biofuel cell with an outstanding power density of 5.4 mW cm−2 at 0.7 V cell voltage was reported by Schuhmann and his coworkers [89]. The redox polymer could effectively protect highly sensitive [FeFe]-hydrogenase under 5% O2 (Fig. 7b). O2-tolerant hydrogenases have broad prospects as catalysts for HBFCs. For instance, Wait et al. assembled the [NiFe]-hydrogenase Hyd-1 from E. coli together with a fungal multicopper oxidase into a bio-battery that could power a digital timer in an H2/O2 gas mixture [90]. A suite of different materials and chemicals, such as carbon-based materials [91], metal-based materials [94], or conductive polymers [89] have been exploited to improve the stability and power density of HBFCs. As seen in Fig. 7(c), Hyd-1 from E. coli and Mv-BOD were covalently attached to multiwalled carbon nanotubes pre-coated on graphite via 1-pyrenebutyric acid functionalities [91]. In the same group, the loadings of both Hyd-1 and Mv-BOD were further increased by Xu et al. by exploiting three-dimensional (3D) compacted mesoporous carbon (CMC). The resulting EBFC achieved power output exceeding 1 mW cm−3 in a membrane-less set-up [95]. This CMC electrode was later upgraded to a compacted porous carbon (CPC) 3D electrode in which case parallel and series connections were adopted to improve the overall cell performance. The CPC 3D electrode was more stable under aerobic conditions using both O2-tolerant hydrogenase Hyd-1 and O2-sensitive (standard) hydrogenase Hyd-2 from E. coli [96] . 4.2 Hydrogenase and nitrogenase HBFCs for N2 fixation The anodic H2 oxidation can also be coupled to reactions and cascades other than O2 reduction such that more valuable products or intriguing overall reactions are obtainable [92,93]. The relevant studies are of great importance in fundamental studies and also in the fields of the fine chemical and pharmaceutical industry. Dinitrogen (N2) is the most abundant gas in the atmosphere and the source of nitrogen-containing industrial and natural compounds [97]. The reduction of N2 to ammonia (NH3) is chemically challenging and, in the industry, is operated by the Haber–Bosch process (N2 + 3H2 → 2NH3), which requires the use of metal catalysts under high temperatures and pressures [98,99]. As nature has evolved a superb N2 fixing enzyme – nitrogenase – that uses N2 and H2 to produce NH3 under ambient conditions, scientists have poured efforts to design HBFCs for N2 fixation [100]. Minteer et al. established a bio-electrocatalytic N2-fixing and NH3-production system using isolated MoFe nitrogenase and Fe protein as the catalysts for the biocathode (Fig. 7d) [92]. Methyl viologen was exploited as the electron mediator, carrying electrons in the form of MV+· from the electrode to the Fe protein through which the MoFe protein accepts electrons and adenosine triphosphate (ATP) hydrolysis was achieved. In the anode-containing compartment, a [NiFe]-hydrogenase was used as the H2-consuming catalyst. The achieved Faradaic efficiency for NH3 production was 26.4%. This system demonstrates the possibility of using renewable energy to support bioelectrochemical N2 fixation and NH3 synthesis [92]. Minteer’s group also developed a self-powered EBFC in which case chemically inert N2 can be converted to chiral amino acids. In this set-up, H2 oxidation was catalyzed by a thermostable [NiFe]-hydrogenase (SHI) on the anode, and the reduction of N2 and NH3 production was catalyzed by nitrogenase, respectively. The generated NH3 was coupled with a diaphorase and leucine dehydrogenase (LeuDH) to achieve asymmetric amination of α-keto acids, resulting in chiral amino acids with high Faradaic efficiency and enantiomeric excess [101]. 4.3 Hydrogenase and various enzymes HBFCs for chemicals Formate, with great commercial value as a raw chemical material and hydrogen carrier, is the CO2 fixation product catalyzed by formate dehydrogenase (FDH) at a low redox potential of −0.42 V vs. SHE (pH = 7.0) [102]. Based on the biological formate-hydrogenase (FHL) complex which links FDH with hydrogenase and produces H2 and CO2 from formate by mixed acid fermentation in E. coli., Sokol et al. developed an electrochemical and colloidal semi-artificial FHL system that exploited ITO as the conductive base to incorporate FDH and DvH-hydrogenase [93]. The in vitro system benefited from efficient linkage of highly active enzyme pairs and allowed for reversible conversion of formate to H2 and CO2 production under ambient temperatures and pressures (Fig. 7e). The combination of the excellent catalytic performance of oxidoreductases and the cofactor regenerating ability of electro-synthetic systems is a promising method to produce fine chemicals, pharmaceuticals, building blocks, and precursors of compounds with high added value [103]. Yuan et al. reported monooxygenase-catalyzed selective electroenzymatic oxidative functionalization in HBFCs [104]. Chen et al. applied a LeuDH in an enzymatic electrosynthesis system (H2/ α-ketoacid HBFC) to produce L-norleucine and its derivatives. In that case, electrons generated from H2 oxidation at the hydrogenase-based anode were transferred to the cathode where the reducing equivalent MV+· was produced. Methyl viologen radicals then drove the N2-fixation reaction catalyzed by a nitrogenase and regeneration of the nicotinamide cofactor NADH catalyzed by a diaphorase, respectively. This cascade was then coupled with the LeuDH which took NH4 + (NH3) and NADH as the substrates produced from the last step, finally resulting in the production of L-norleucine and 2-ketohexanoic acid. This H2/ α-ketoacid EBFC can also be used to produce L-norvaline, L-valine, L-tert-leucine, and L-cyclopropyl glycine with high enantiomeric excess [101]. 5 Enzymatic electricity-hydrogen-carbohydrate cycle Despite the elegance of the abovementioned hydrogen production and utilization schemes, it remains an open question that whether these delicate hydrogenase-containing reactors can ultimately be applied in industry and match their inorganic catalysts-using equivalents. The key to the answer lies in the cost in all aspects from enzyme expression, enzyme activity and stability, the set-up of the reactor, the efficiency in inputting and outputting energy, the conditions for hydrogen storage, etc. Here, this section introduces a representative in vitro synthetic enzymatic biosystem (ivSEB) with vivid examples, mainly contributed by Zhang and his colleagues, which cover these essential topics and can give insights into the future industrial applications of hydrogenases. 5.1 The exploration of hydrogenase yield Due to the complexity of hydrogenase molecules which include the metal-containing active sites and multi-[FeS] clusters, the expression, maturation and purification often suffer from cumbersome procedures and lead to low yield. For example, the [FeFe] hydrogenase from Clostridium pasteurianum W5 could be obtained ∼0.14 mg (g of cell)−1 [105]. Fusion of algal ferredoxin (Fd) and [FeFe]-hydrogenase HydA1 allowed to remove Fd and resulted in HydA1 purification yields of 5 mg (L of culture)-1 from E. coli [106]. The yield of [NiFe]-hydrogenase is also low. A more efficient process for acquiring Hyd-2 [NiFe]-hydrogenase from E. coli has been developed, resulting in a yield of approximately 0.15 mg (g of cell)−1 [44]. The soluble [NiFe]-hydrogenase I (SHI) from Pf. (PfSHI) is among the most used ones in fundamentals studies due to its remarkable thermostability with a half-life of 14 h at 90 °C and O2 tolerance at low temperature. Like Hyd-2 from E. coli., the original wildtype PfSHI enzyme had equally low yield which was ∼0.025 mg protein (g of cell)−1. Song et al. managed to express the four subunits of PfSHI in Thermococcus kodakarensis KOD1 – a hyper-thermophilic archaeon with a complete set of hydrogenase maturation apparatus. The resulting 12-Hig tagged recombinant PfSHI can be overexpressed, with over 1200-fold enhancement in the hydrogenase activity from the cell lysate [37]. 5.2 Enzymatic hydrogen production powered by carbohydrates Zhang et al. proposed a novel scheme coined as the “electricity-hydrogen-carbohydrate” (EHC) cycle where three forms of secondary energy can be generated from either renewable or non-renewable source and interconverted with one another using the in vitro synthetic enzymatic biosystem (ivSEB) with high theoretical efficiency [107], as shown in Fig. 8 (a). While this review mainly focuses on hydrogenase-catalyzed reactions and the H2-electricity interrelation has been well introduced before, the remaining section will direct to the carbohydrates-to-H2 conversion. Key studies of EHC cycle can be referred to in these literatures [108–111]. The reasons for incorporating carbohydrate as the source for storing and generating hydrogen are due to the following key information: (1) the carbohydrate has exceedingly high energy density which is approximately ten-fold than that of conventional lithium-ion batteries and compressed H2; (2) the carbohydrate can be obtained in gigantic scale from plants, straws, and industrial waste (∼1 billion tons in China); (3) the theoretical high efficiency for interconverting hydrogen and carbohydrate can be achieved using the ivSEB and can even break the 100% limit under special conditions [112–115]. The scheme of proof-of-concept is illustrated in Fig. 8(b). In a series of delicate coupled enzyme-catalyzed reactions, the chief starting substrate (C6H10O5) n can be transformed into H2 and CO2. The net reaction is C6H10O5 (aq) + 7H2O (l) = 12H2 (g) + 6CO2 (g) [116]. One can see that apart from C6H10O5 and H2O, all reactants, including the precious ATP, ribulose 5-phosphate (Ru5P) glucose 6-phosphate (G6P), and NADPH involved are regenerated, meaning that the cost of the whole reaction system can be minimized [117]. The key step for generating hydrogen is catalyzed by the NADPH-dependent soluble hydrogenase PfSHI (2NADPH + 2H+ = 2H2 + 2NADP+). It is worth mentioning that the whole reaction is downhill (△G 0 = −49.8 kJ mol−1) and this serves as the reason why the theoretical yield can surpass 100% [116,118]. The extraordinary H2 production efficiency was initially confirmed by using glucose and 13 different enzymes originating from bacteria, yeast, animals, plants, archaea, etc., with 5.19 mol H2 (mol of glucose) -1 production rate being recorded [119]. The sugar to be used was not limited to glucose, as the starch [117], cellulose [118], xylose [120], sucrose [109], etc., are all proven to be high-performance substrates for H2 production. As illustrated in Fig. 8(b), the enzymes cocktails are exploited and the intermolecular transfer pathways can be redesigned according to the variant of carbohydrates. In a delicate reactor using five different thermophiles and starch as the sugar source, every glucose unit can give rise to 12 mol H2 molecules. As NADPH is not thermodynamically favored for PfSHI-catalyzed H2 production at the neutral pH, attempts were made to introduce electron mediators for more efficient electron delivery to the hydrogenase molecules. When benzyl viologen (BZ) and a NADPH rubredoxin oxidoreductase were used, the maximum H2 production rate was promoted to 310 mmol L−1h−1 [121]. This value can be further enhanced to 530 mmol L−1h−1 at 80 °C when the NADPH-dependent cascade from G6P to Ru5P was altered to be NADH-dependent, together with the BV and the diaphorases being coupled [117,122]. 5.3 Driving tomorrow with carbohydrate-hydrogen power Once the 530 mmol L−1h−1 H2 production rate can be increased by tenfold, the threshold for applying the sugar-to-H2 reactor to a sugar powered automobile is reached [117]. As the power density of carbohydrates substantially outperforms compressed H2, gasoline and lithium batteries, the spontaneous H2 evolution using the ivSEB is expected to generate concentrated and pure H2 which can be exploited immediately in a H2-based fuel cell set-up to power an electricity-using system, particularly an electric vehicle (Fig. 8b). This is a holy grail of the hydrogen economy. 6 Conclusions and perspective To improve the O2 tolerance of hydrogenases, changing structures and properties of hydrogenases using the genetic modification technique is straightforward. The engineering sites can be introduced on or near the active site, the gas delivery channel, and amino residues accounting for the functionality of the electron relay ([FeS] clusters) by the structural or artificial intelligence assisted evolution methods. The insights from the already-existed hydrogenases with O2 tolerance, such as the O2 tolerant [NiFe]-hydrogenase, [NiFeSe]-hydrogenase, and the [FeFe]-hydrogenase of which the “Hinact” state that can be reversed, are important to guide the design of new variants. Alternatively, seeking external support to avoid the attack from O2 can be achieved (1) biologically – by wiring the protein with an O2-scavenging partner or (2) physically – by introducing a physical barrier to block the diffusion pathway of O2 or (3) a combination of physical and chemical methods, which are the cases for applying redox polymers. The synthetic materials-assisted strategy can be analogous to dressing hydrogenase molecules with extra armors such that the stability of the biocatalytic assembly and reliability of the reactor can be further enhanced. So far, no way can deal with all situations. The possible strategy should depend on real application scenarios. Except for the oxygen tolerance, the photostability [123,124] and thermostability [37,121] are also important factors for further utilization of hydrogenase, which deserve further studies. Hydrogenases have been extensively studied as H2-producing biocatalysts in a series of artificial photosystems to produce high-purity hydrogen using solar energy. For these photocatalytic assemblies, the O2 tolerance of hydrogenases, durability of the photochemical device, biocompatibility between the materials and biomolecule, and the intrinsic light-capturing capability of the assembly are all essential factors that should be considered. An especially intriguing scheme is the combination of hydrogenase with PSI/PSII to carry out water splitting without or with minimal potential bias. Future efforts in this field will focus on coordinating the photoelectric dynamics of materials and fitting them with bio-catalysts in terms of time, space and energy, so as to promote their practical application prospects in biotechnology essentially. Using the ivSEB system to produce high-quality H2 is a promising and practically viable strategy capitalizing the high-power density of sugar which has abundant sources in nature. Because the carbohydrate-to-hydrogen reaction involves multi-enzymatic cascades, the optimization of factors in each step, including the enzymes, ingredients and reaction conditions, can all boost the overall reaction rate. The H2 production rate has been increased from ∼0.5 to 530 mmol L−1h−1 at 80 °C and it is gradually approaching the ultimate standard to fuel an automobile in an electricity-hydrogen- carbohydrate cycle. Hydrogenase-based biofuel cells are of practical importance; they can be used to generate electric power or synthesize high-value-added products. The EBFCs using hydrogenases and O2-reducing enzymes benefit from these facts: (1) The overpotential to drive the complete reaction is minimized. (2) The use of enzymes is free from precious metal catalysts. (3) HBFCs have the best efficiencies under ambient temperatures and pressures. (4) No ion exchange membrane is required. So far, the benchmark power density of ∼mW cm−2 has been achieved. To improve the power output, the loading and stability of biocatalysts should be further increased. The coupling of hydrogenase-based EBFCs with another electroactive enzyme(s) to form cascade reactions with high value-added compounds as the final products is extremely promising and is practically ensured by high selectivity of enzymes on their substrates and products. In summary, hydrogenases have shown great potential in H2 production and utilization. The structure or computer assisted evolution methods will promote hydrogenase to achieve oxygen tolerance and wide application. The assemblies of hydrogenase and photoelectric materials can not only be utilized for generating clean hydrogen energy, but also for producing valuable compounds in the fields of biosynthesis and biomedicine. In particular, the ivSEB system provides another thinking to perform enzymatic H2 production powered by carbohydrate. Hydrogen therapy is an emerging and promising therapy strategy of using molecular hydrogen as a new type of safe and effective therapeutic agent [125]. Controllable and biocompatible hydrogen production system will provide great potential for remarkable therapeutic effects on many oxidative stress-/inflammation-related diseases owing to the bio-reductivity and homeostatic regulation ability of the H2. All these studies are inspiring and will encourage the academia to pour more ideas and talents for future advances. Mater. 8 (2019) e1900463. Haishuo Ji is now a Ph.D. candidate at Nankai University under the supervision of Professor Liyun Zhang. His work focuses on hydrogenase-based biohydrogen production and application. Lei Wan obtained his D.Phil. in Inorganic Chemistry from the University of Oxford under the supervision of Professor Fraser A. Armstrong. He is currently an Alexander von Humboldt Fellow working in Professor Serena DeBeer’s department at the Max Planck Institute of Chemical Energy Conversion. He uses spectroscopic techniques to study light-induced reactions of hydrogenase. Yanxin Gao is currently a Ph.D. candidate under the supervision of Professor Liyun Zhang at Nankai University. His research focuses on developing enzyme-based artificial photosynthesis systems for CO2 fixation and hydrogen production. Ping Du is a Ph.D. candidate at Nankai University under the supervision of Professor Liyun Zhang. His research is to reveal the synergistic interaction mechanism among multiple iron-sulfur clusters in multi-subunits of formate dehydrogenase. Wenjin Li is currently a Ph.D. candidate at Nankai University under the supervision of Professor Liyun Zhang. Her current research interests focus on the catalytic mechanism of hydrogenase and formate dehydrogenase. Hang Luo is a Master student at Nankai University under the supervision of Professor Liyun Zhang. His research interests are NADH cycle regeneration and efficient multi-enzyme cascade catalysis. Jiarui Ning is a Master student at Nankai University under the supervision of Professor Liyun Zhang. His research focuses on the efficient production of biohydrogen by microbial light-dark fermentation Yingying Zhao is a Master student at Nankai University under the supervision of Professor Liyun Zhang. Her work focuses on hydrogen evolution by the artificial photosynthesis system of hydrogenase. Huangwei Wang is a Master student at the East China University of Science and Technology under the supervision of Professor Zhang Lixin. He is currently committed to transforming Nitrogenase in Rhodopseudomonas globosa from molecular genetics and protein-directed evolution in order to obtain a Rhodopseudomonas globosa chassis with higher hydrogen production potential. Lixin Zhang is the Director of the National Key Laboratory of Bioreactor Engineering at East China University of Science and Technology, China. His research interest is mainly focused on increasing the production titers of microbial natural products through synthetic biology strategy. Liyun Zhang is currently a professor at Nankai University. She received her Ph.D. from the University of Science and Technology of China. She was a winner of the Newton international fellowship under the supervision of Professor Fraser A. Armstrong for hydrogenase-based H2 production and utilization at the University of Oxford. Her current scientific interests are enzyme-based artificial photosynthesis for H2 production and CO2 conversion, bio-catalysis, and bioanalysis.

coredata.dc:description: Hydrogenase is a paradigm of highly efficient biocatalyst for H2 production and utilization evolved in nature. A dilemma is that despite the high activity and efficiency expected for hydrogenases as promising catalysts for the hydrogen economy, the poor oxygen tolerance and low yield of hydrogenases largely hinder their practical application. In these years, the enigmas surrounding hydrogenases regarding their structures, oxygen tolerance, mechanisms for catalysis, redox intermediates, and proton-coupled electron transfer schemes have been gradually elucidated; the schemes, which can well couple hydrogenases with other highly efficient (in)organic and biological catalysts to build novel reactors and drive valuable reactions, make it possible for hydrogenases to find their niches. To see how scientists put efforts to tackle this issue and design novel reactors in the fields where hydrogenases play crucial roles, in this review, recent advances were summarized, including different strategies for protecting enzyme molecules from oxygen, enzyme-based assembling systems for H2 evolution in the photoelectronic catalysis, enzymatic biofuel cells for H2 utilization and storage and the efficient electricity-hydrogen-carbohydrate cycle for high-purity hydrogen and biofuel automobiles. Limitations and future perspectives of hydrogenase-based applications in H2 production and utilization with great impact are discussed. In addition, this review also provides a new perspective on the use of biohydrogen in healthcare beyond energy.
